The '''Thai lunar calendar''' ({{lang-th|ปฏิทินจันทรคติ '''Pa ti thin Chan tha ra kha ti'''}}) (literally, ''Against-the-Sun Moon-Ways''), '''Dai calendar''' (傣历), or '''[[Tai peoples|Tai]] calendar''', is [[Thailand]]'s version of the [[lunisolar calendar|lunisolar]] [[Buddhist calendar]]. It is used in the [[southeast Asia]]n countries of [[Cambodia]], [[Laos]] and [[Myanmar|Burma]] for calculating lunar-regulated holy days. Based on the third-century ''[[Surya Siddhanta]]'' (a [[Hindu calendar]]), these combine [[lunar calendar|lunar]] and [[solar calendar]]s for a nominal [[year]] of 12 [[month]]s. An extra day or an extra 30-day month is [[Intercalation (timekeeping)|intercalated]] at regular intervals; Thai, Lao, and Cambodian versions do not add an extra day to years with an extra month.
==Legal v. religious calendar== The [[Thai solar calendar]] (''Patitin Suriyakati'', {{lang-th|ปฏิทินสุริยคติ}}), Thailand's version of the [[Gregorian calendar]], replaced the ''Patitin Chantarakati'' in [[calendar era#Dionysian_.22Common_Era.22|AD]] 1888 / 2431 [[Calendar_era#Religious|BE]] for [[Civil law (legal system)|legal]] and [[Commerce|commercial]] purposes. In both calendars, the four principal [[lunar phase]]s determine [[Buddhist]] Sabbaths ([[uposatha]]), obligatory holy days for observant Buddhists. Significant days also include feast days. [[Thai Chinese]] likewise observe their Sabbaths and [[traditional Chinese holidays]] according to lunar phases. These move with respect to the solar calendar, so common Thai calendars incorporate both Thai and [[Chinese calendar|Chinese]] lunar dates for [[religion|religious]] purposes.
[[Mundane astrology]] also figures prominently in [[Thai culture]], so modern Thai birth certificates include lunar calendar dates and the appropriate [[Chinese calendar]] zodiacal animal year-name for both Thai [[Hora (astrology)|Hora]] ({{lang|th|โหราศาสตร์ ''โหราสาต'' ho-ra-sat)}} and [[Chinese astrology]].
==Years== {{see also|Lunar phase}}
To keep the years in sync with the seasons, Thai lunar years may add a day to the 7th month or repeat the 8th month. Therefore, years may have one of three lengths – 354, 355 or 384 days – yet retain a [[Real versus nominal value|nominal]] length of twelve months.
*'''354''' day-long years consist of 12 "normal months", and such a year is called a "normal-month year" ({{lang|th|ปกติมาส (ปีปะกะติมาด Pee-pa-ga-ti-mat)}}).
*'''355''' day-long years [[Intercalation (timekeeping)|add]] an extra day to the normally 29-day-long 7th month; such a year is called an "extra-day year" ({{lang|th|ปีอธิกวาร (ปีอะทิกะวาน Pee-a-ti-ga-wan)}}).
[[File:August2004rs.png|right|thumb|175px|AD 2004/2547BE Extra lunar month ended August 15]] *'''384''' day-long years repeat the 30-day-long 8th month, thus keeping the month count at 12. Nevertheless, a year of 384 days is called an "extra-month year" ({{lang|th|ปีอธิกมาส (ปีอะทิกะมาด Pee-a-ti-ga-mat)}}).
===New year=== The Thai lunar calendar does not mark the beginning of a new year when it starts a new 1-to-12 count, which occurs most frequently in December.
[[Image:August2004 1-2.jpg|right|thumb|August 1 and 2, 2004. Sunday, a holiday, on the left, and Monday, observed as the compensatory day, on the right]] The Thai solar calendar determines a [[person]]'s [[legal age]] and the dates of [[Secularity|secular]] [[holiday]]s, including the civil [[new year]] and the three days of the traditional [[Thai New Year]]. Should the holidays fall on a [[Workweek|weekend]], it also accommodates these as well as some of the principal [[lunar festival]]s with a compensatory day off {{lang|th|''วันชดเชย'' wan chot chuey}}.
For Thai Chinese communities in Thailand, the Chinese calendar] determines the day that a year assumes the name of the next animal in the twelve-year animal cycle. In the traditional Thai lunar and solar calendars, however, the new zodiacal animal year-name changes on [[Songkran (Thailand)|Songkhran]] (April 13).<ref>{{cite book|title=The calendrical systems of mainland southeast asia|author=J.C. Eade|isbn=90-04-10437-2|publisher=E.J. Brill, Leiden|page=22}} According to some scholars including [[George Coedes]], the change originally occurred at the beginning of the 5th lunar month, a few days before Songkhran.</ref>

==Months==
In the modern Thai calendar, months (''Deuan'', {{lang-th|เดือน}}, meaning "month" or "[[Lunation]]") are defined by lunar cycles. Successive months (or lunations) are numbered from 1 to 12 within the Thai year. As in other [[Buddhist calendar]]s, these months have names that derive from [[Buddhist_calendar#Names_of_the_months|Sanskrit]], but for the most part are only known by Thai astrologers.<ref name=Diller>{{cite web |url= http://dspace.anu.edu.au/bitstream/1885/41890/3/thai_time.html |title= Thai Time |accessdate= 2008-05-08 |last= Diller |first= Anthony |coauthors= Preecha Juntanamalaga |year= 2000 |publisher= Faculty of Asian Studies Australian National University |page= 25 |archiveurl = http://dspace.anu.edu.au/bitstream/1885/41890/3/thai_time.html |archivedate= 2002-01-10 |quote= (5.1) ...names would be known only by Thai astrologers (Prasert Na Nagara 1998:524).}}</ref>
Two successive lunations take slightly more than 59 days. The Thai lunar calendar approximates this interval with "normal-month" pairs ({{lang|th|ปรกติมาสฅ ปกกะติมาด Pok-ga-ti-mat)}} that are alternately 29 and 30 days long. 29-day "[[Month#Calendrical consequences|hollow month]]s" ({{lang|th|เดือนขาด deuan kàat}}) are odd-numbered ({{lang|th|เดือนคี่ deuan kêe}}); 30-day "full months" ({{lang|th|เดือนถ้วน deuan tûan}}) are even-numbered ({{lang|th|เดือนคู่ deuan kôo}}).
To keep the beginning of the month in sync with the new moon, from time to time either the normally "hollow" Month 7 takes an extra day, or an extra "full" Month 8 follows a normal "full" Month 8.
Months 1 and 2 are named in [[Archaism|archaic]] [[Thai numerals#Alternate numbers|alternate numbers]], with the remainder being named in modern numbers.<ref name=Diller>{{cite web |url= http://dspace.anu.edu.au/bitstream/1885/41890/3/thai_time.html |title= Thai Time |accessdate= 2008-05-08 |last= Diller |first= Anthony |coauthors= Preecha Juntanamalaga |year= 2000 |publisher= Faculty of Asian Studies Australian National University |page= 25 |archiveurl= http://dspace.anu.edu.au/bitstream/1885/41890/3/thai_time.html |archivedate= 2002-01-10 |quote= (5.1) ...the common Thai practice is simply to refer to lunar months by number, ''e.g.'' [du’an s:am], ‘third lunar month’. For the first and second lunar months, the older Thai counting forms [a:y] and [yi:] are used. Thus the first lunar month is commonly [du’an a:y], equivalent in more obscure astrological parlance to [maru’khasira-ma:t].}}</ref>
=== Months 1 – 6 === Month 1, "Deuan Aai" ({{lang|th|เดือนอ้าย}}), begins the cycle of counting the months anew, most frequently in December, but does not signify the beginning of a new year.<ref name=Diller>{{cite web |url= http://dspace.anu.edu.au/bitstream/1885/41890/3/thai_time.html |title= Thai Time |accessdate= 2008-05-08 |last= Diller |first= Anthony |coauthors= Preecha Juntanamalaga |year= 2000 |publisher= Faculty of Asian Studies Australian National University |page= 25 |archiveurl= http://dspace.anu.edu.au/bitstream/1885/41890/3/thai_time.html |archivedate= 2002-01-10 |quote= (5.1) [Month 1] refers to a full moon occurring near the designated part of Orion, which most frequently happens in December. }}</ref> '''Aai''', an [[Archaism|archaic]] word in Thai but not in other dialects, means ''first-born'' (or ''eldest'').<ref name=ORID>[http://rirs3.royin.go.th/dictionary.asp On-line Royal Institute Dictionary] (ORID - 1999). </ref> An odd-numbered hollow month, it is 29 days long.
Month 2, "Deuan Yi", ({{lang|th|เดือนยี่}} from archaic ญี่ meaning ''2'')<ref name="ORID"/> is an even-numbered full month.
Months 3–6, "Deuan 3–6", use the modern reading of [[Thai numerals]], as do all remaining months. Months 3–6, alternate between 29-day hollow months and 30-day full months.
=== Month 7 and Atigawan === Month 7, "Deuan 7", a hollow month is normally 29 days long in years of 354 days, but adds an extra day ({{lang|th|อธิกวาร (อะทิกะวาน A-ti-ga-wan)}}) when required for 355-day-long years ({{lang|th|ปีอธิกวาร (ปีอะทิกะวาน Pee-a-ti-ga-wan}})).
===Month 8 === The eighth month, "Deuan 8", is a 30-day full month.
=== Month 8/8 "Atigamas" === [[Image:July 14 2007.jpg|150px|right]] [[Image:July 15 2007.jpg|150px|right]] "Atigamas ({{lang|th|อธิกมาส (อะทิกะมาด a-ti-ga-mat)}}) is the extra month needed for a 384-day-long ''piathikmas'' (extra-month year - {{lang|th|ปีอธิกมาส (ปีอะทิกะมาด Pee-a-ti-ga-mat}}). Month 8 repeats as เดือน ๘/๘ Month 8/8, variously read as "Deuan pat thap pat" ({{lang|th|เดือนแปดทับแปด}}) — "Month 8 slash 8", "Deuan pat song khang" ({{lang|th|เดือนแปดสองข้าง}}) — "Month 8 Side Two", or "Deuan pat song Hon" ({{lang|th|เดือนแปดสองหน}}) — "Month 8 Time Two".
===Months 9 – 12 === Months 9–12, "Deuan 9–12", complete the lunar cycle.
===Month divisions=== Months divide into two periods designated by whether they are [[Lunar_phase#Names_of_lunar_phases|waxing or waning]]: *Waxing : ''Khang Kuen'' ({{lang|th|ข้างขึ้น}}), the period from new moon to full moon, is always 15 days long. *Waning : ''Khang Raem'' ({{lang|th|ข้างแรม}}), the period from full moon to new moon, which is 14 days long in hollow months, except when Month 7 adds an extra day, and 15 days long in full months.

ORID --> A [[week]] is called {{lang-th|สัปดาห์}} or {{lang|th|สัปดาหะ}}, pronounced {{lang|th|สับ-ดา}} sàb-da, {{lang|th|สับ-ปะ-ดา}} sàb-phà-daa, or {{lang|th|สับ-ดา-หะ}} sàb-da-hà}}. From a [[Sanskrit]] word for "seven", it is now defined by the [[Royal_Institute_of_Thailand#The_Royal_Institute_Dictionary|Royal Institute Dictionary]] (RID) as a 7 day period beginning on Sunday and ending Saturday. <ref>[http://rirs3.royin.go.th/dictionary.asp RID on-line]</ref> When referring to lunations, however, it is the 7-, 8- or (rarely) 9-day interval between [[quartile]] [[lunar phase]]s; that is, from one {{lang|th|วันพระ wan prà}} to the next.
==Days== While [[Thai_solar_calendar#Weekdays|solar-calendar weekdays]] have names, lunar-calendar days number sequentially from 1 to 14 or 15 in two segments depending on whether the moon is waxing or waning. For example, "Raem 15 Kham Deuan 12 {{lang|th|แรม ๑๕ ค่ำ เดือน ๑๒}}" means "Waning 15 Evening [of] Month 12".
''Kham {{lang|th|ค่ำ}} '', evening, is considered to be the evening of the common day that begins and ends at midnight, rather than of a day that begins and ends at dusk. Past practice may have been different.
==Named lunar days== *''Wan Phra'' {{lang|th|วันพระ}}, Buddhist holy days **''Wan Thamma Sawana'' {{lang|th|วันธรรมสวนะ (วันทำมะสะวะนะ)}} Buddhist Sabbath regularly fall on: ***''Kuen 8'' {{lang|th|ขึ้น ๘}} first-quarter moon ***''Kuen 15'' {{lang|th|ขึ้น ๑๕}} full moon; also called ''Wan Phen'' {{lang|th|วันเพ็ญ}} day [of] full [moon]. However, ''Wan Deuan Phen'' {{lang|th|วันเดือนเพ็ญ}}, the actual day of the [[Full moon#Characteristics|full moon]] and Khuen 15 Kham do not always fall on the same day. ***''Raem 8'' {{lang|th|แรม ๘}} third-quarter moon ***''Raem 14 (15)}}'' {{lang|th|แรม ๑๔ (๑๕)}} the last day of the lunar month; also called ''Wan Dab'' {{lang|th|วันดับ}} day [moon is] quenched, [or goes] out. *''Wan Wy Phra Chan'' {{lang|th|วันไหว้พระจันทร์}}, called "Day [of] Respect [for] the Holy Moon", is the actual day the [[Harvest moon]] becomes full. It occurs on ''Kuen 14 (15) Kham Deuan 10'' {{lang|th|ขึ้น ๑๔ (๑๕) ค่ำ เดือน ๑๐}} (Waxing 14(15) Evening, Month 10.)
==Holidays regulated by the moon== {{Main|Public holidays in Thailand}} [[Uposatha|Buddhist Sabbaths]], colloquially called {{lang|th|วันพระ Wan Phra}}, are the New, First-quarter, Full, and Third-quarter Moon-days. These are not normally days off ({{lang|th|วันหยุด '''wan-yoot'''}}), except for [[butcher]], [[barber]], and [[beautician]] shops that observe the [[Eight Precepts]]. Annual holidays and seasonal festivals collectively are called {{lang|th|วันนักขัตฤกษ์ วันนักขัดตะเริก '''Wan nak-khad-ta-roek'''}}.
Festivals or [[fair]]s are called {{lang|th|เทศกาล (เทสะกาน) '''thet-sa-garn'''}}; these may be further styled as {{lang|th|ประเพณี ''pra-pen-nee''}} "[[tradition]]al" and as {{lang-th|พืธิ ''pit-ti''}}, "[[rite]]" or "[[ceremony]]". The table shows the [[Uposatha#Special_uposatha|principal]] ones governed by the moon in yellow.
Work holidays prescribed by the government are called {{lang-th|วันหยุดราชการ วันหยุดราชากาน '''Wan-yoot-ra-cha-gan'''}}; those regulated by the moon are red.
Weekends are normally days off; if a holiday normally observed by a day off falls on a weekend, the following Monday is a compensatory day off {{lang-th|วันชดเชย Wan chod-choey}}.

==Thai year vocabulary== Thai orthography spells most native words phonetically, though there is no definitive system for [[Royal Thai General System of Transcription|transcription]] into Roman letters. Here, native Thai words are immediately followed by a vocabulary entry in this pattern: :''Phonetic'' Thai (Thai phonetic respelling, if different) [Comment] definition; variant definitions. Example: :''Thai'' ไทย (ไท) [Archaic] free, frank; Thai race, language, [[Thai alphabet|alphabet]] ; [[thaification|citizen of Thailand]].
[[Sanskrit]] loan words follow different rules [the way English grammatical rules vary for words of Greek and Latin origin ('ph-' in 'phonetic' being pronounced /f/, for example.)] Entered below in order of first appearance, these vocabulary entries are in this pattern: ;''Sanskrit'' สันสกฤต (สันสะกริด /san-sa-krit/) : Literally means "self-made" or "self-done", or "cultured" in a modern usage (which implies the language of cultured persons); Sanskrit alphabet, [[Sanskrit language|language]], writing; [presumed] compound of * ''san'' สัน (-/son/) derived from the word, "saṃ" meaning "self, together, with" * ''skrit'' สกฤต (สะกริต /sa-krit/) derived from the word "(s)kar" meaning "do or make". ; ''Chantarakati'' จันทรคติ (จันทะระคะติ) : Lunar Calendar; compound of * ''Chantara-'' จันทร- (จันทะระ /chontara/) : ''Chon'' จันทร์ (จัน) moon, lunar + * ''Kati'' คติ (คะติ) : ways, principles; moral [of a tale]. ; ''Patitin'' ปฏิทิน (ปะติทิน) : Calendar; compound of * ''Pati-'' ปฏิ- (ปะติ-) : anti-, re- + * ''-tin'' (-ทิน) : [from ''tinnagorn'' ทินกร (ทินะกอน) - poetical for] the sun, Sol **[possibly in the sense of 'tint' + ''- gorn'' -กร – -er, -or: paint-er]. ; ''Patitin Chantarakati'' ปฏิทินจันทรคติ (ปะติทินจันทะระคะติ) : "Resolarized Moon-Ways", Lunisolar Calendar ; ''Suriyakati'' สุริยคติ (สุริยะคะติ) : ''Solar Ways'', Solar Calendar; compound of * ''Suriya'' สุริย or สุริยะ : ''Athit'' อาทิตย์, the sun, Sol + * ''Kati'' คติ (คะติ) : ways, principles; moral [of a tale]. ; ''Prokatimas'' ปรกติมาส (ปฺรกกะติมาด /pro-ko-ti-maht/) : normal month; compound of * ''Prokati'' ปรกติ (ปฺรกกะติ) : ''pokiti'' ปกติ (ปะกะติ) ordinary, usual, normal + * ''Mas'' มาส (มาด /maht/) : du-an (เดือน) month. ; ''Athikamas'' อธิกมาส (อะทิกะมาด /a-ti-ka-maht/) : month added in leap-month lunar years ; ''Athikawara'' อธิกวาร (อะทิกะวาน /a-ti-ka-wahn/) : day added in leap-day lunar years; compound of * ''Athika'' (Sanskrit: adhika) : additional + * ''-wara'' วาร (วาน /wahn/) : ''wan'' วัน day. ;''Athikasuratin'' อธิกสุรทิน (อะทิกะสุระทิน) : day added to February in a solar leap year.
